title: Germany’s Commerzbank Names New CFO Amid Strategy Revamp
text:
The Commerzbank AG logo sits on a sign outside the bank's headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, on Monday, July 1.

Commerzbank AG on Thursday named a new finance chief, a move that comes as Germany’s second largest bank is revamping its strategy in response to challenging market conditions.

The Frankfurt-based bank said Bettina Orlopp will succeed Stephan Engels as its chief financial officer no later than March 31, 2020. Ms. Orlopp is currently in charge of Commerzbank’s compliance, human resources and legal departments. Before that, she was responsible for group development and strategy. Ms. Orlopp joined Commerzbank in 2014.

The bank earlier this month said Mr. Engels, its CFO since 2012, would leave next spring to become finance chief at Danske Bank A/S.

Commerzbank AG on Thursday named Bettina Orlopp as its new finance chief. Photo: Courtesy Commerzbank AG Commerzbank’s supervisory board recently approved a new strategy dubbed Commerzbank 5.0, which is supposed to help the bank navigate negative interest rates, tight margins and a weakness in its corporate clients business. “Over the course of 2019, the market environment has continued to deteriorate further,” the bank said in a statement. Newsletter Sign-up As part of its overhaul, Commerzbank plans to invest €750 million ($820 million) into digitization efforts, new information technology infrastructure and growth plans. The bank said it will cut 2,300 full-time positions—resulting in €850 million in restructuring costs—and divest its majority shareholding in Polish lender mBank SA. Commerzbank’s cost base is set to come down by €600 million to €5.5 billion or less in 2023, following the sale of the mBank stake, the bank said in the earlier press release. Group revenue fell to €4.28 billion in the first six months of the year, down from €4.39 billion in the prior year period, while operating profit declined to €542 million, down from €659 million. “The agenda [for the bank] is clear,” said Daniele Brupbacher, an analyst at UBS Group AG. “And the industry headwinds are also more than clear,” she said. Merger talks between Deutsche Bank AG and Commerzbank earlier this year collapsed, as both banks cited the costs and complexity of a potential transaction. She has successfully and prudently mastered many difficult issues,” Mr. Zielke said, according to a release. Write to Nina Trentmann at Nina.Trentmann@wsj.com
